references: The results of our main experiments are displayed in TableÂ 1. We also display the results of the centralized training on each dataset in AppendixÂ K. The main conclusion is, our method can consistently bring improvement to all baselines on both image and text classification tasks in almost all settings. Note that though the standard deviation in each experiment in TableÂ 1 may seems a bit large compared with the improvement gap, we point out that actually on almost each seed of one specific experiment, applying our method can gain the improvement over the corresponding baseline. We put the result on each seed in AppendixÂ Q for comparison.

(3) When comparing the results in TableÂ 1 with the results on Î±=1.0ğ›¼1.0\alpha=1.0 in TableÂ 6 in AppendixÂ L, we can get that on each dataset, the trend is the improvement brought by our method is greater if the non-i.i.d.Â degree is larger (i.e., smaller Î±ğ›¼\mathbf{\alpha}). Our explanation is when the label distribution is more skewed, the impact of client sampling becomes larger. More analysis is in AppendixÂ L.

Firstly, we find SGDM is more suitable to train CNNs and Adam is more suitable to train Transformer-based models. Thus we choose the client optimizer as SGDM when training on two image classification datasets, and choose the client optimizer as Adam for two text classification datasets. Then we perform centralized training on each dataset in order to find the optimal client learning rate Î·lsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘™\eta_{l} and batch size BğµB, and use that learning rate and batch size as the local training hyper-parameters for all federated optimization baselines in the federated training setting. The optimal local training hyper-parameters for each dataset are listed in TableÂ 13. To decide the number of local training epoches for each dataset, we tune it from {1,3,5,10}13510\{1,3,5,10\} by using FedAvg, and use the tuned one for other optimization baselines.

We allow each baseline to tune its own optimal server learning rate in each data partition setting. The server learning rate search grids for all baseline methods are displayed in TableÂ 14. We also display the server learning rates we have tuned and used in our main experiments in TableÂ 15. The server learning rates used for the baseline methods in SectionÂ 5.2 and SectionÂ 5.3 are re-tuned, since we find the optimal server learning rates under different sampling ratios or different sampling strategies are different.

For FedProx, we allow it to tune its own hyper-parameter Î¼ğœ‡\mu from {1.0,0.1,0.01,0.001}1.00.10.010.001\{1.0,0.1,0.01,0.001\} in each data partition setting, and we display the best Î¼ğœ‡\mu in each setting in TableÂ 12. As we can see, there is no general Î¼ğœ‡\mu for all settings, and researchers may carefully tune this hyper-parameter in each setting.

As we can see, FedGLAD can also consistently bring improvement in this setting, which validates the effectiveness of our method. However, compared with the results in TableÂ 1 in the main paper, we find that on each dataset, the overall trend is the improvement brought by our method are greater if the non-i.i.d.Â degree is larger (i.e., smaller Î±ğ›¼\mathbf{\alpha}). Our explanation is when the label distribution is more skewed, the impact of client sampling becomes larger. For example, when data is more non-i.i.d.Â and the sampled clients have the similar but skewed local data distributions, the averaged server gradientâ€™s direction will deviate far more away from the ideal direction that we assume is averaged by all clientsâ€™ local gradients. Thus, it becomes more important to adjust the server learning rates in these scenarios.

We use FedAvg and FedAvgM as baselines, and the non-i.i.d.Â degree Î±=0.1ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1. Other details can be found in TableÂ 16. The results are in TableÂ 8. As we can see, since BiLSTM is not pre-trained, the performance gap between the federated training and the centralized training is larger than that of using DistilBERT as the backbone under the same number of communication rounds.
Secondly, after applying our learning rate adaptation mechanism, the performance consistently becomes better. The experimental results validate the effectiveness of our method on the BiLSTM.

As we mentioned in our paper in the experiment analysis section (SectionÂ 4.3), the standard deviation in each experiment in TableÂ 1 and TableÂ 6 may seems a bit large compared with the improvement gap. However, we display the result on each seed of our method and baselines (take FedAvg and FedAvgM as examples) in the TableÂ P and TableÂ P, we point out that actually on almost each seed of one specific experiment, applying our method can gain the improvement over the corresponding baseline. The large standard deviation of the baseline results are mainly caused by the fact that the large non-i.i.d. degree makes the baseline training sensitive to the random seeds.

references: Here we provide the detailed descriptions of the datasets and models we used in our experiments in TableÂ 4. We get data from their public releases. Since these datasets are widely used, they do not contain any personally private information. Some of them do not have the public licenses, so we give all the public links to the datasets we use in the following. Following previous studiesÂ (Reddi etÂ al., 2020), we use all original training samples for federated training and use test examples for final evaluation. We tune the hyper-parameters based on the averaged training loss of the previous 20% communication roundsÂ (Reddi etÂ al., 2020).

A10.T5.table:
CIFAR-10 MNIST 20NewsGroups AGNews
91.86 (Â±plus-or-minus\pm 0.49) 99.26 (Â±plus-or-minus\pm 0.04) 84.12 (Â±plus-or-minus\pm 0.05) 93.43 (Â±plus-or-minus\pm 0.07)
references: In the main experiments, we fix the sampling ratio as 0.10.10.1. Here, we explore our methodâ€™s performance in the settings where 5, 10, 20 out of 100 clients are sampled in each round. The optimal server learning rates for baselines are re-tuned here. The results are in TableÂ 5.2. The overall trend is the improvement brought by our method is more significant when the sampling ratio is smaller. That is because when the number of sampled clients increases, the merged data distribution of sampled clients is more likely to be consistent with the merged data distribution of all clients, thus the impact of client sampling decreases.

In this subsection, we want to show that our method can also be combined with other sampling mechanisms besides the normal one used in our main experiments. We conduct experiments with two additional sampling strategies: (1) Multinomial Distributionâ€“based Sampling (MD)Â (Fraboni etÂ al., 2021b): considering sampled clients as rğ‘Ÿr i.i.d.Â samples from a Multinomial Distribution; (2) Dynamic Attention-based Sampling (AdaFL)Â (Chen etÂ al., 2021): dynamically adjusting the sampling weights of clients during the training. The sampling ratio is 0.1. The results in TableÂ 5.2 show that our method can also work well with these sampling strategies, since they aim to sample better groups of clients in each round while our method improves the learning after the sampling results are determined.

For comparison with the results in the federated training setting, we display the results on all datasets in the traditional centralized training setting in TableÂ 5. The training settings and hyper-parameters on each dataset are kept as the same as that in the local training of the federated learning.

references: (3) When comparing the results in TableÂ 1 with the results on Î±=1.0ğ›¼1.0\alpha=1.0 in TableÂ 6 in AppendixÂ L, we can get that on each dataset, the trend is the improvement brought by our method is greater if the non-i.i.d.Â degree is larger (i.e., smaller Î±ğ›¼\mathbf{\alpha}). Our explanation is when the label distribution is more skewed, the impact of client sampling becomes larger. More analysis is in AppendixÂ L.

The results are in TableÂ 6(a). As we can see, (1) when the local optimizer is Adam (i.e., experiments on 20NewsGroups), the ratios are all less than 0.2 in all settings, and the ratios are smaller when Î±ğ›¼\alpha is smaller or the number of epochs decreases. This indicates that when Adam is the local optimizer, our assumption that the squared norms of local gradients are almost the same across clients can hold well. (2) When the local optimizer is SGDM (i.e., experiments on CIFAR-10), the ratios become larger as expected. However, even when the number of local epochs is 5 and Î±=0.1ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1, the ratio is smaller than 1/3131/3, so our assumption that the scale component is barely affected by the client sampling compared with the direction component still roughly holds, and the experimental results also validate the effectiveness of our method even when we choose SGDM as the local optimizer. An interesting phenomenon in CIFAR-10 is, when Î±=1.0ğ›¼1.0\alpha=1.0, the ratio becomes smaller as the number of local epochs increases, but is still smaller than that when Î±=0.1ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1. Our explanation is, when the number of local epochs is small, the randomness (e.g., data random shuffle, dropout) during the local training plays a great role; and when the number of local epochs is large enough, the scale of each local gradient is stable and only depends on the local training objective.

Besides the non-i.i.d. degrees we set in our main paper to conduct the main experiments, we also explore the performance of our method when Î±=1.0ğ›¼1.0\alpha=1.0. The baselines and the settings are the same as that in the main experiments, and the results are in TableÂ 6.

As we mentioned in our paper in the experiment analysis section (SectionÂ 4.3), the standard deviation in each experiment in TableÂ 1 and TableÂ 6 may seems a bit large compared with the improvement gap. However, we display the result on each seed of our method and baselines (take FedAvg and FedAvgM as examples) in the TableÂ P and TableÂ P, we point out that actually on almost each seed of one specific experiment, applying our method can gain the improvement over the corresponding baseline. The large standard deviation of the baseline results are mainly caused by the fact that the large non-i.i.d. degree makes the baseline training sensitive to the random seeds.
